title: Japan's Ruling Party Gains Supermajority in Key Election
summary: Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) achieved a significant victory in Japan's parliamentary election, securing a two-thirds supermajority in the lower house. Preliminary results reported by NHK show the LDP won 316 seats, surpassing the absolute majority of 261 in the 465-seat chamber and setting a record since the party's founding in 1955. With its ally, the Japan Innovation Party, adding 36 seats, the ruling coalition holds 352 seats total. Takaichi, Japan's first female prime minister, emphasized her readiness to pursue policies aimed at strengthening Japan's economy and military capabilities amid growing tensions with China and efforts to nurture ties with the United States. Despite recent scandals and funding issues within the LDP, Takaichi called an early election after only three months in office to capitalize on her high popularity. This supermajority allows her to advance a right-wing agenda more effectively, even without a majority in the upper house, as she pledges to be flexible and seek opposition support while pushing forward her goals.

background_read: Japan's political system features a bicameral parliament with a lower house (more powerful) and an upper house. The Liberal Democratic Party has dominated Japanese politics for decades, often facing issues like funding scandals. A supermajority in the lower house allows for easier legislative passage, including potential constitutional amendments. Takaichi's rise as the first female prime minister reflects changing dynamics, and her right-wing agenda focuses on economic and military strengthening amid regional tensions, particularly with China, while aligning with the U.S. Early elections are strategic moves to consolidate power during high public approval.
